title: R44625
content: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) offers benefits such as medical care, disability compensation, education, vocational rehabilitation, home loan guarantees, and burial expenses for veterans and eligible dependents. These services are provided nationwide through three administrations and the Board of Veterans Appeals (BVA). The Veterans Health Administration (VHA) provides health care services and medical research programs for veterans. It offers primary care, specialized care, and social support services through the nation's largest integrated health care system. Inpatient and outpatient care are also available for eligible dependents of veterans under the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veterans Affairs (CHAMPVA). The VA budget includes mandatory funding for disability compensation, pensions, education, and burial benefits. The VA budget includes funding for education, life insurance, housing, burial benefits, medical care, research, construction programs, and general operating expenses. Various accounts, revolving funds, trust funds, and special funds support these services. Congress authorized advance appropriations for three VHA accounts in 2009. In 2014, Congress passed the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 (H.R. 83; P.L. 113-235), which amended 38 U.S.C §117 to include three more accounts for advance appropriations within the Veterans Benefits Administration. This act authorizes advance appropriations for three mandatory VA benefits programs: compensation and pensions, readjustment benefits, and veterans insurance and indemnities. Additionally, the FY2016 Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act (MILCON- VA; P.L. 114-113) provided advance appropriations for FY2017 for these accounts, along with the three VHA accounts already authorized. Section 4003 of the Surface Transportation and Veterans Health Care Choice Improvement Act of 2015 (P.L. 114-41) mandated the creation of a new account for medical community. The FY2017 MILCON-VA Act established a new account for medical community care, funded by rescinding amounts from the 2017 medical services account. Advance appropriations were authorized to prevent delays in care and benefits for veterans in case of funding lapses. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 provides advance appropriations for various veterans' accounts for FY2017. Funding for FY2016 does not include these advance appropriations, which are shown in the FY2017 column under "memorandum." Similarly, FY2018 advance appropriations are provided in the Continuing Appropriations Act. The Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 (P.L. 113-146 as amended by P.L. 113-175, P.L. 113-235, P.L. 114-19, P.L. 114-41, and P.L. 115-26) aims to improve access to medical care at VA facilities. It establishes the Veterans Choice Program to authorize care for veterans outside the VA health care system if they meet certain criteria. The Veterans Choice Program was established by Congress with $10 billion in funding over three years. President Trump signed a law to extend the program and allow unobligated funds to be used until expended. However, due to increased usage of funds, the program could not continue past August 15, 2017. The Veterans Choice Program (VCP) would not continue past August 15, 2017, as all remaining funds would be obligated by then. To sustain VCP through FY2018, $3.5 billion in new mandatory budget authority was required. President Trump signed the VA Choice and Quality Employment Act of 2017, allocating $2.1 billion for the Veterans Choice Fund. An additional $5 billion in mandatory funding was provided to enhance veterans' access to healthcare and improve VA infrastructure. The President's FY2017 budget request for the Department of Veterans Affairs was approximately $177.54 billion, including $102.53 billion in mandatory funding and $75.01 billion in discretionary appropriations, a 9.14% increase over the FY2016-enacted level. The Veterans Choice Fund is not included in this report as it falls outside the scope of the appropriations acts mentioned. The FY2017 budget request for the Department of Veterans Affairs is $177.54 billion, with $102.73 billion allocated for disability compensation, readjustment benefits, and veterans insurance. The Veterans Health Administration's request is $65.66 billion, a 6.30% increase over FY2016, including additional funding for medical care accounts. The President's FY2017 budget request for the Department of Veterans Affairs includes funding for caregiver programs, infrastructure improvements, and leasing of medical facilities. A new account for VHA, medical community care, would fund care provided to eligible veterans through community providers. The budget request also includes $170.32 billion in advance appropriations for FY2018 for VHA and VBA, with highlights such as $528.11 million for construction major projects and a decrease in IT program funding. The FY2017 Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, and Related Agencies appropriations bill requested $1.24 billion for construction programs and $4.27 billion for IT programs, representing a 3.50% increase from FY2016. The House and Senate actions on the bill were outlined from April 2016 to September 29, 2016, with the House passing a measure providing $176.06 billion for the VA, a slight decrease of 0.83%. The House-passed measure provides $176.06 billion for the VA, including $102.53 billion in mandatory appropriations and $73.53 billion in discretionary appropriations. $64.79 billion is allocated for VHA, with an additional $864 million for various programs compared to the Administration's request. The House-passed bill, H.R. 4974, provides $7.24 billion for a new medical community care account by transferring funds from other accounts. It also allocates $102.70 billion for VBA programs, a 12.33% increase from FY2016, and slightly less than the President's request. The House-passed bill, H.R. 4974, provides $14.97 million less than the President's request for Cemetery Administration. For information technology programs, it allocates $4.22 billion, a 1.22% decrease from the requested amount. The funding level includes an increase over fiscal year 2016 for priority areas such as Veterans Benefits Management System and electronic health record modernization. The House-passed bill increased the account by $5 million by reducing the general administration account by a similar amount. The bill provides advance appropriations for medical care and mandatory benefit program accounts for FY2018. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved its version of the FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations bill. The Senate used the FY2016 THUD appropriations bill as the vehicle for the FY2017 MILCON-VA bill, providing $177.39 billion for VA, a 9.04% increase over FY2016. The bill includes $102.53 billion in mandatory appropriations and $74.85 billion in discretionary appropriations. Division B of H.R. 2577 provides $105.58 billion for VBA programs, including $2.85 billion in VBA general operating expenses. Prior to the FY2012 MILCON-VA appropriations bill, VBA general operating expenses were included with departmental general operating expenses. Division B also allocates $65.52 billion for VHA, with $1.57 billion over FY2017 advance appropriations for medical care accounts and $675.36 million for medical and prosthetic research. The House-passed measure and the President's request provide funding for a new medical community care account by transferring funds from other medical accounts. The Senate-passed version of the MILCON-VA appropriations bill includes a provision for fertility treatment for veterans with service-connected conditions. The Senate-passed bill includes funding for fertility treatment for veterans with service-connected conditions, along with authorization provisions for veterans programs. The bill provides advance appropriations for medical care and mandatory benefit program accounts for FY2018, matching the President's request. The House concurred with the Senate amendment and a conference agreement was reached between House and Senate Republican Members. The conference agreement between House and Senate Republicans on the FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations bill and Zika Response and Preparedness Act was approved by the House. The Senate failed to invoke cloture on the agreement multiple times before S.Amdt. 5082 to H.R. 5325 was proposed by Senator McConnell. H.R. 5325 became the legislative vehicle that included the full year FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations Act. Division A of P.L. 114-223 contains the FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations act. Division A of P.L. 114-223 allocated $176.89 billion for VA programs, including $105.58 billion for VBA programs and $65.27 billion for VHA. A separate medical community care account was established for non-VA care funding starting in FY2017 as per P.L. 114-41. The Health Care Choice Improvement Act (P.L. 114-41) consolidates VA programs for veterans' care from non-VA providers. Funding for medical community care is $7.25 billion for FY2017 and $9.41 billion for FY2018. The FY2017 MILCON-VA Appropriations Act allocated $4.28 billion for information technology programs. Construction projects received $528.11 million from Division A of P.L. 114-223. The FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations act allocated $528.11 million for construction projects. It includes provisions to prevent cost overruns and establish a process for VA employees to file whistleblower complaints. The FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations act allocated $528.11 million for construction projects and established a new process for VA employees to file whistleblower complaints. This new process allows employees to file complaints with their immediate supervisors and includes a central whistleblower office to investigate all complaints. Retaliation against whistleblowers will result in disciplinary action, including suspension or removal of supervisors. Under the new provisions, VA supervisors can be removed for a second offense, and whistleblower complaints will impact their performance evaluation. The FY2017 MILCON-VA appropriations act allows the use of funds for fertility treatments and adoption reimbursement for veterans with service-connected disabilities. VA must develop implementing guidance within 120 days of the act's enactment. The VA published regulations allowing IVF treatment for eligible veterans and fertility counseling for spouses. The authority for these services using ART would end in September 2018. The Jason Simcakoski Memorial and Promise Act aims to improve opioid safety for veterans with chronic pain. The Jason Simcakoski Memorial and Promise Act aims to improve opioid safety among veterans with chronic pain by establishing an office of patient advocacy within the VA health care system. President Trump signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017, providing $50 million for opioid and substance abuse prevention and treatment in support of the Act. The Promise Act (P.L. 114-198) provided additional funding for the VA in FY2017, totaling approximately $176.94 billion. Of this amount, $74.40 billion is discretionary appropriations and $102.53 billion is mandatory appropriations. The total funding for VHA in FY2017 was $65.32 billion.
